sn22.88:1.1: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.
sn22.88:1.2: Now at that time Venerable Assaji was staying in a monastery built by a Kassapa, and he was sick, suffering, gravely ill.
sn22.88:1.4: “Please, reverends, go to the Buddha, and in my name bow with your head to his feet. Say to him:
sn22.88:1.5: ‘Sir, the mendicant Assaji is sick, suffering, gravely ill.
sn22.88:1.6: He bows with his head to your feet.’
sn22.88:1.8: ‘Sir, please go to the mendicant Assaji out of sympathy.’”
sn22.88:1.9: “Yes, reverend,” those monks replied. They did as he asked.
sn22.88:2.1: Then in the late afternoon, the Buddha came out of retreat and went to Venerable Assaji.
sn22.88:2.2: Venerable Assaji saw the Buddha coming off in the distance,
sn22.88:2.3: and tried to rise on his cot.
sn22.88:2.4: But the Buddha said to him,
sn22.88:2.5: “It’s all right, Assaji, don’t get up.
sn22.88:2.6: There are some seats spread out, I will sit there.”
sn22.88:2.7: He sat on the seat spread out and said,
sn22.88:2.8: “I hope you’re keeping well, Assaji; I hope you’re all right. And I hope the pain is fading, not growing, that its fading is evident, not its growing.”
sn22.88:3.1: “Sir, I’m not all right, I’m not getting by. My pain is terrible and growing, not fading, its growing is evident, not its fading.”
sn22.88:3.2: “I hope you don’t have any remorse or regret?”
sn22.88:3.3: “Indeed, sir, I have no little remorse and regret.”
sn22.88:3.4: “I hope you have no reason to blame yourself when it comes to ethical conduct?”
sn22.88:3.5: “No sir, I have no reason to blame myself when it comes to ethical conduct.”
sn22.88:3.6: “In that case, Assaji, why do you have remorse and regret?”
sn22.88:3.7: “Sir, before my time of illness I meditated having completely stilled the physical process. But now I can’t get immersion.
sn22.88:3.8: Since I can’t get immersion, I think:
sn22.88:3.10: “There are, Assaji, ascetics and brahmins for whom samādhi is the essence, equating immersion with the ascetic life. They think:
sn22.88:4.7: They understand: ‘… there is nothing further for this place.’
sn22.88:4.8: If they feel a pleasant feeling, they understand that it’s impermanent, that they’re not attached to it, and that they don’t relish it.
sn22.88:4.9: If they feel a painful feeling, they understand that it’s impermanent, that they’re not attached to it, and that they don’t relish it.
sn22.88:4.10: If they feel a neutral feeling, they understand that it’s impermanent, that they’re not attached to it, and that they don’t relish it.
sn22.88:4.11: If they feel a pleasant feeling, they feel it detached.
sn22.88:4.12: If they feel a painful feeling, they feel it detached.
sn22.88:4.13: If they feel a neutral feeling, they feel it detached.
sn22.88:4.14: Feeling the end of the body draw close, they understand: ‘I feel the end of the body draw close.’ Feeling the end of life draw close, they understand: ‘I feel the end of life draw close.’
sn22.88:4.15: They understand: ‘When my body breaks up and my life is over, everything that’s felt, being no longer relished, will become cool right here.’
sn22.88:5.1: Suppose an oil lamp depended on oil and a wick to burn.
sn22.88:5.2: As the oil and the wick are used up, it would be extinguished due to not being fed.
sn22.88:5.3: In the same way, feeling the end of the body draw close, they understand: ‘I feel the end of the body draw close.’ Feeling the end of life draw close, they understand: ‘I feel the end of life draw close.’
sn22.88:5.4: They understand: ‘When my body breaks up and my life is over, everything that’s felt, being no longer relished, will become cool right here.’”
